0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• General anesthesia; Adjunct: induction, 0.3-3 mg/kg IV over 10-15 min
  • General anesthesia; Adjunct: maintenance, 0.25-0.5 mg/kg in single IV administrations, as needed
  • Pain (Moderate to Severe): 10 mg subQ, IM or IV for a 70 kg individual repeated every 3 to 6 hours as needed; MAX single dose is 20 mg/dose; MAX total daily dose is 160 mg/day
  • Pain (Moderate to Severe), Including preoperative, postoperative, and obstetrical analgesia: 10 mg subQ, IM or IV for a 70 kg individual repeated every 3 to 6 hours as needed; MAX single dose is 20 mg/dose; MAX total daily dose is 160 mg/day
  • Shivering, Postanesthesia: 0.08 mg/kg IV

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in patients under 18 years of age

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • General anesthesia; Adjunct
  • Pain (Moderate to Severe)
  • Pain (Moderate to Severe), Including preoperative, postoperative, and obstetrical analgesia
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Opioid analgesic adverse reaction - Respiratory depression
  • Pruritus of skin
  • Shivering, Postanesthesia
  • Sickle cell anemia with crisis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity to nalbuphine or to any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• biliary tract surgery; spasm of the sphincter of Oddi may occur
  • bradycardia has been reported in patients who did not receive atropine preoperatively
  • concomitant use of central nervous system depressants including alcohol, general anesthetics, hypnotics, opioid analgesics, phenothiazines, sedatives, or tranquilizers
  • emotionally unstable patients; monitoring recommended with prolonged use
  • head injury; respiratory depression or increases in cerebrospinal fluid pressure may be exaggerated; may obscure clinical course of injury
  • hepatic impairment; dose reduction recommended
  • intracranial lesion or preexisting increase in intracranial pressure; respiratory depression or increases in cerebrospinal fluid pressure may be exaggerated
  • myocardial infarction with nausea or vomiting
  • opioid abuse; monitoring recommended with prolonged use
  • renal impairment; dose reduction recommended
  • respiration impairment (eg, due to bronchial asthma, cyanosis, respiratory obstructions, concomitant medications, severe infection, uremia); increased risk respiratory depression; lower doses advised; reversible by naloxone

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Nalbuphine: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Diaphoresis (up to 9%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea and vomiting (6%), Xerostomia (4%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (up to 5%), Headache (3%), Sedated (36%), Vertigo (up to 5%)
Serious
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (1% or less)
  • Neurologic:Loss of consciousness, Seizure
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary edema, Respiratory depression (1% or less)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Nalbuphine hydrochloride is a phenanthrene opioid analgesic with binding affinity to mu, kappa, and delta receptors with no affinity to sigma receptors, but acts primarily as a kappa agonist/partial mu antagonist.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• pain reduction, improvement in ability to move
  • mental and respiratory status
  • bowel movements
  • signs and symptoms of withdrawal

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    Injection Solution: 10 MG/ML, 20 MG/ML
  • Amerinet Choice Nalbuphine Hydrochloride
    Injection Solution: 10 MG/ML, 20 MG/ML
  • Novaplus Nalbuphine Hydrochloride
    Injection Solution: 10 MG/ML, 20 MG/ML
  • Nubain
    Injection Solution: 10 MG/ML, 20 MG/ML

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Patient should avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness or sedation.
  • This drug may cause sweating, constipation, nausea, or vomiting.
  • Patient should report depression.
  • Advise patient against sudden discontinuation of drug, as this may cause narcotic withdrawal symptoms, especially in patients on chronic therapy.
  • If self-administered, teach patient proper technique and placement of injections.
  • Advise patient to rotate injection sites.
  • Patient should not use alcohol or other CNS depressants while taking this drug.
